qas.question: What makes glass melt at a lower temperature?
How much less viscous is lead glass compared with soda glass?
Pb2+ causes lead glass to have what?
Lead oxide makes it easier to dissolve what?
What makes glass melt higher than soda?
How much less viscous is lead glass compared with lead?
Pb2+ causes bubbles to have what?
Lead oxide makes it easier to decrease viscosity in what?
What makes the Pb2+ ion vitreous?

context: Addition of <a0_0><b4_0>lead(II) oxide<b4_0/><a0_0/> lowers melting point, lowers viscosity of the melt, and increases refractive index. Lead oxide also facilitates solubility of <a3_0><b7_0>other metal oxides<b7_0/><a3_0/> and is used in colored glasses. The viscosity decrease of lead glass melt is very significant (roughly <a1_0><b5_0>100 times<b5_0/><a1_0/> in comparison with soda glasses); this allows easier removal of bubbles and working at lower temperatures, hence its frequent use as an additive in vitreous enamels and glass solders. The <b8_0>high ionic radius<b8_0/> of the Pb2+ ion renders it highly immobile in the matrix and hinders the movement of other ions; lead glasses therefore have <a2_0><b6_0>high electrical resistance<b6_0/><a2_0/>, about two orders of magnitude higher than soda-lime glass (108.5 vs 106.5 Ohm·cm, DC at 250 °C). For more details, see lead glass.
